name: Expanding Horizons
description: 30 words to elevate your academic writing

words.definition: Obedient or attentive to an excessive degree; servile.
examples: The obsequious waiter hovered at their table constantly.
His obsequious behavior toward the boss was embarrassing.

words.definition: A person who acts obsequiously to gain advantage; a flatterer.
examples: The king was surrounded by sycophants who agreed with everything.
She refused to be a sycophant to advance her career.
distractors: A person who avoids social interaction.

words.definition: Unwilling to spend money or use resources; stingy.
examples: The parsimonious millionaire lived in a modest apartment.
Her parsimonious habits helped her save for retirement.

words.definition: Having a ready insight into and understanding of things.
examples: The perspicacious detective noticed every detail.
Her perspicacious analysis impressed the committee.

words.definition: Showing a casual lack of concern; indifferent.
examples: She gave an insouciant wave as she left the party.
His insouciant attitude masked his deep anxiety.

words.definition: Carried out with minimum effort; cursory.
examples: He gave a perfunctory nod without really listening.
The perfunctory inspection missed obvious problems.
distractors: Done with great care and attention.

words.definition: Optimistic or positive, especially in a bad situation.
examples: Despite the setbacks, she remained sanguine about success.
His sanguine disposition made him popular at parties.

words.definition: Behaving as though one thinks one is superior to others.
examples: The supercilious waiter looked down on the casual diners.
Her supercilious tone offended everyone in the room.

words.definition: Complaining in a petulant or whining manner.
examples: The querulous customer demanded to see the manager.
His querulous voice grated on everyone's nerves.

words.definition: Not telling the truth; lying.
examples: The mendacious politician was eventually exposed.
Her mendacious claims were contradicted by evidence.

words.definition: Tending to talk a great deal; talkative.
examples: The loquacious tour guide kept everyone entertained.
After a few drinks, he became quite loquacious.

words.definition: Very attentive to detail; concerned about accuracy.
examples: The fastidious editor caught every typo.
She was fastidious about cleanliness in her kitchen.

words.definition: Given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood.
examples: The capricious weather ruined their picnic plans.
Her capricious boss changed priorities daily.

words.definition: Characterized by vulgar or pretentious display; showy.
examples: His ostentatious mansion drew criticism from neighbors.
The ostentatious jewelry seemed inappropriate for the funeral.

words.definition: Kept secret, especially because improper.
examples: She took a surreptitious glance at her phone during the meeting.
His surreptitious activities were eventually discovered.

words.definition: Expressing opinions loudly and forcefully.
examples: The vociferous protesters blocked the street.
His vociferous objections delayed the vote.

words.definition: Having a harmful effect, especially gradually.
examples: The pernicious rumors destroyed her reputation.
Smoking has pernicious effects on health.

words.definition: Stubbornly uncooperative toward authority.
examples: The recalcitrant student refused to follow rules.
Management struggled with recalcitrant union members.

words.definition: Make a problem or bad situation worse.
examples: His comments only exacerbated the conflict.
The drought was exacerbated by poor water management.

words.definition: Make something bad or unsatisfactory better.
examples: New policies helped ameliorate living conditions.
Nothing could ameliorate his grief.

words.definition: Make something clear; explain.
examples: The professor tried to elucidate the complex theory.
Could you elucidate your reasoning?

words.definition: Confirm or give support to a statement or theory.
examples: Witnesses corroborated her account of events.
The data corroborated the hypothesis.

words.definition: Spread information widely.
examples: Social media helps disseminate news quickly.
The organization works to disseminate health information.

words.definition: Overwhelm with things to be dealt with.
examples: The office was inundated with applications.
Complaints inundated the customer service line.

words.definition: Remove or prevent a difficulty.
examples: The new system will obviate the need for paperwork.
Proper planning can obviate many problems.

words.definition: Prevent from happening; make impossible.
examples: The weather may preclude outdoor activities.
This decision precludes other options.

words.definition: An inclination or natural tendency to behave in a particular way.
examples: He has a propensity for taking risks.
Her propensity toward kindness was well known.

words.definition: A tendency to choose or do something regularly.
examples: His proclivity for gambling worried his family.
She has a proclivity for solving puzzles.

words.definition: The ability to make good judgments and quick decisions.
examples: Her business acumen led to great success.
Political acumen is essential for diplomats.

words.definition: The quality of having good judgment; wisdom.
examples: The leader was known for her sagacity.
His sagacity helped navigate the crisis.
